Review Text: I was enjoying it until the blood and dismembered body parts, only a few minutes in. At that point I stopped watching. What a waste of an otherwise seemingly original and intriguing movie.
Review Title: Ruined by Gore

Not a patch on the book. Bryson's wit replaced with vulgarity. Completely lacking in the true challenge of the experience. Ending anticlimactic. Insipid. I guess the money was too tempting. Only redeeming feature of this film was the acting.
Disappointment.
{'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'frightening scenes', 'alcohol use', 'smoking', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['Français'], 'Subtitles': ['English'], 'Directors': ['Anne Fontaine'], 'Producers': ['Eric Altmayer', 'Nicolas Altmayer'], 'Starring': ['Lou de Laage', 'Agata Buzek', 'Agata Kulesza'], 'Studio': ['Music Box Films']}
A profound movie about the atrocities of war. Beautifully crafted, visually stunning, bleak and stark, but with moments of utter tenderness, I found it as heartwarming and it was painful. The atrocities themselves were not depicted, and this absence was the work of genius that left room for an examination of the depths and heights humanity can reach. There is hope to be found, and much love, and for some, faith. I'm so glad I found out about this film. I loved it. So very thought provoking.
Profound movie, refreshing in its simplicity.
{'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Hope Dickson Leach'], 'Producers': ['Rachel Robey'], 'Starring': ['Ellie Kendrick', 'David Troughton', 'Jack Holden'], 'Studio': ['Monterey Media']}
A massive festival of human and animal misery and nothing else. Miserable people, miserable circumstances, miserable setting. Thoroughly depressing and unconvincing. Overacted, overwritten. Truly wretched. A study in how people do not behave in reality, no matter how dire the circumstances.
One Dimensional.
A Street Cat Named Bob
Drama, Kids, Cheerful, Emotional
['Based on the international bestselling book. The true, feel-good story of how James Bowen, a busker and recovering drug addict, had his life transformed when he met a stray ginger cat.']
{'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Roger Spottiswoode'], 'Producers': ['Adam Rolston'], 'Starring': ['Luke Treadaway', 'Ruta Gedmintas', 'Joanne Froggatt']}
This was a sweet film handled very well. Full of hope and love but not overly sugar coating the grit and dangers of drugs and homelessness, it shows how the companionship of a remarkable animal can sometimes be the one thing that pulls people through really tough times. There were some very compassionate and loving humans involved too. Really glad I watched it. A unique story that made such a change from the doom and gloom of so much of what passes as entertainment. This would appeal to a wide age range I believe, and obviously a broad audience. I'm so happy for the success of all involved.
Uplifting Power of Animals

Just a sweet Christmas film with a religious theme that's uplifting more than annoying. I allowed myself to be swept into it, and enjoyed every moment of its sentimentality. Very beautiful scenery. British acting well done. Susan Boyle! If only it could be true...
Unapologetically Sweet

Beautiful and tender. I've heard the story of Vincent Van Gogh's life several times before, but this was the first time it really hit me in the heart. This movie is a masterpiece, the art of film at its finest. I plan to watch it again. I can count on one hand the number of movies I've said that about, and I've seen a lot!
Now I think I know...
{'Audio languages': ['Español'], 'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['Pablo Larraín'], 'Producers': ['Juan De Dios Larraín'], 'Starring': ['Gael García Bernal', 'Luis Gnecco', 'Mercedes Morán']}
I watched it in two parts because I was fed up after half way through. This is the type of movie you might watch and discuss in a film appreciation class. It's overly esoteric. It needs an interpretation (not the language but the "meaning"). For those who are into film studies, I imagine it would be enjoyable. I was disappointed in the lack of clarity, the depressing, muddy depiction of Chile, and most of all Neruda, who used to be one of my favorite poets. I am all for arty, literary movies, but this one left me cold and confused. It's a difficult movie to watch with subtitles because it requires a lot of visual concentration. At one point I wondered if the color settings on my tv had been altered by mistake.
Bleak and Confusing
{'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'alcohol use', 'foul language'], 'Audio languages': ['English', 'English [Audio Description]'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Stephen Frears'], 'Producers': ['Tim Bevan', 'Eric Fellner', 'Beeban Kidron', 'Tracey Seaward'], 'Starring': ['Judi Dench', 'Ali Fazal', 'Eddie Izzard'], 'Studio': ['Focus Features']}
The movie was just what I was in the mood for. I probably won't remember it for long, but it was enjoyable. Judi "wonderful as usual" Dench was wonderful as usual. The acting was very good all the way around. If not for that and the scenery it would have been perhaps a three star movie or even less. The reason? Because they used so much contemporary dialogue, including a lot of swearing, which coming from the mouths of the characters was jarring rather than amusing. Did they do it to avoid a PG rating? The opening scene even looks like it might be set today. They didn't quite pull it off, the mixture of contemporary and Victorian. I also didn't much appreciate the role of comics that the Indian characters were given in the beginning. The whole movie was on the shallow side. I would like to read the book to get to the heart of what is actually quite a deep story. However, in spite of all that, it gets four stars from me because I enjoyed it a lot anyway.
Swearing out of place.
The Holiday
Cameron Diaz  (Actor),     Kate Winslet  (Actor),     Nancy Meyers  (Director, Producer)    &                   0                  more   Rated:    PG-13    Format: DVD
Movies & TV, Holidays & Seasonal, Christmas, Comedy
['Product Description', "In Nancy Meyers'", 'The Holiday', ', a romantic comedy from the director of', "Something's Gotta Give", 'and', 'What Women Want', ", two women trade homes only to find that a change of address can change their lives. Iris (Winslet) is in love with a man who is about to marry another woman. Across the globe, Amanda (Diaz), realizes the man she lives with has been unfaithful. Two women who have never met and live 6000 miles apart, find themselves in the exact same place. They meet online at a home exchange website and impulsively switch homes for the holiday. Iris moves into Amanda's L.A. house in sunny California as Amanda arrives in the snow covered English countryside. Shortly after arriving at their destinations, both women find the last thing either wants or expects: a new romance. Amanda is charmed by Iris' handsome brother Graham (Law) and Iris, with inspiration provided by legendary screenwriter Arthur (Wallach), mends her heart when she meets film composer Miles (Black).", 'Amazon.com', 'As a pleasant dose of holiday cheer,', 'The Holiday', 'is a lovable love story with all the Christmas trimmings. In the capable hands of writer-director Nancy Meyers (making her first romantic comedy since', "Something's Gotta Give", '), it all begins when two successful yet unhappy women connect through a home-swapping website, and decide to trade houses for the Christmas holiday in a mutual effort to forget their man troubles. Iris (Kate Winslet) is a London-based journalist who lives in a picture-postcard cottage in Surrey, and Amanda (Cameron Diaz) owns a movie-trailer production company (leading her to cutely imagine most of her life as a "coming attraction") and lives in a posh mansion in Beverly Hills. Iris is heartbroken from unrequited love with a cad of a colleague (Rufus Sewell), and Amanda has just broken up with her cheating boyfriend (Edward Burns), so their home-swapping offers mutual downtime to reassess their love lives. This being a Nancy Meyers movie (where everything is fabulously decorated and romantic wish-fulfillment is virtually guaranteed), Amanda hooks up with Iris\'s charming brother Graham (Jude Law), and Iris is unexpectedly smitten with Miles (Jack Black), a super-nice film composer on the downside of a failing relationship.', '--Jeff Shannon']

Two vacuous (but beautiful) women just can't get their acts together without a man. Saccharine and sappy and cliched. White as white can be.

profile:
The user maintains a strong preference for high-quality narratives that emphasize literary fidelity, emotional depth, and authenticity. They are critical of adaptations that deviate from the source material and exhibit an aversion to excessive vulgarity, favoring sophisticated humor. Their sensitivity to character depth in emotionally driven narratives has grown, as they embrace sentimentality and hope while favoring uplifting films that balance serious themes with connection and companionship.

Recently, the user expressed disappointment with a film they deemed "vacuous," criticizing its clichéd storytelling and lack of depth. This indicates their desire for narratives that illuminate genuine human experiences, reflecting a nuanced engagement with media that seeks emotional resonance alongside clarity in complex themes. They remain vigilant about narrative shallowness, even rating films positively in terms of acting and visuals.

In their latest interaction, they echoed their commitment to profound storytelling by expressing distaste for excessive gore in a film that appeared otherwise intriguing. Their reaction signifies a continued focus on emotional authenticity and sensitivity to inauthentic portrayals of relationships and emotional experiences. Overall, the user appreciates a blend of depth and entertainment, pursuing films that capture the intricacies of humanity while remaining enjoyable and accessible.
